articles.headline: Doubts Greet Treasury Plan on Regulation
articles.snippet: Lawmakers and lobbyists from industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers and lobbyists from industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. laid out an ambitious plan to overhaul the regulatory apparatus that oversees the nation’s financial system on Monday, lawmakers and lobbyists from an array of industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.

articles.headline: On Paper, Wall Street Gets Its Way
articles.snippet: Wall Street for years demanded an overhaul of the system overseeing the American financial system, and may have gotten its wish with the new Treasury plan to do so.
articles.abstract: Wall Street for years demanded an overhaul of the system overseeing the American financial system, and may have gotten its wish with the new Treasury plan to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, when the markets were flying high, a chorus of alarm went up on Wall Street. Talk spread that the United States risked losing its edge in the financial world.

articles.headline: In Gaza, Hamas’s Insults to Jews Complicate Peace
articles.snippet: While the Palestinian Authority has made efforts to end incitement against Israel and Jews, Hamas feels no such restraint.
articles.abstract: While the Palestinian Authority has made efforts to end incitement against Israel and Jews, Hamas feels no such restraint.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  In the Katib Wilayat mosque one recent Friday, the imam was discussing the wiliness of the Jew.

articles.headline: Food Prices Rise, Farmers Respond
articles.snippet: Farmers say they intend to significantly cut corn acreage this year in favor of soybeans, which may help alleviate global shortages that have hit poor countries hard.
articles.abstract: Farmers say they intend to significantly cut corn acreage this year in favor of soybeans, which may help alleviate global shortages that have hit poor countries hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Faced with strong worldwide food demand and the accompanying higher prices, American farmers are beginning to respond to the signals of the market. In a new government report, farmers said they would make significant cuts in corn acreage this year in favor of soybeans.

articles.headline: Insurers Faulted as Overloading Social Security
articles.snippet: Insurers are forcing many people who file disability claims with them to make dubious Social Security applications, lawsuits say.
articles.abstract: Insurers are forcing many people who file disability claims with them to make dubious Social Security applications, lawsuits say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Social Security system is choking on paperwork and spending millions of dollars a year screening dubious applications for disability benefits, according to lawsuits filed by whistle-blowers.

articles.headline: Award Plans Earn Cash for Airlines
articles.snippet: What began as a way to win the loyalty of air travelers has turned into a lucrative business for the airlines.
articles.abstract: What began as a way to win the loyalty of air travelers has turned into a lucrative business for the airlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travelers have been complaining more often about frequent flier programs  namely, the lack of award seats on desirable flights, escalating fees for ostensibly free tickets and quicker expiration dates for miles.

articles.headline: Accusations of Delays in Releasing Drug Results
articles.snippet: A doctor who led a key trial of two heart drugs accused their makers, Merck and Schering-Plough, last July of hiding the negative results.
articles.abstract: A doctor who led a key trial of two heart drugs accused their makers, Merck and Schering-Plough, last July of hiding the negative results.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  The lead outside investigator on a crucial trial of two widely used heart drugs said in an e-mail message last July that Merck and Schering-Plough, the companies that make the drugs, were deliberately delaying the release of the trial results “to hide something.”

articles.headline: Big Plans Are Slow to Bear Fruit in New Orleans
articles.snippet: A year after city officials unveiled a plan to redevelop the city, there are few signs of that transformation.
articles.abstract: A year after city officials unveiled a plan to redevelop the city, there are few signs of that transformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  In March 2007, city officials finally unveiled their plan to redevelop New Orleans and begin to move out of the post-Hurricane Katrina morass. It was billed as the plan to end all plans, with Paris-like streetscape renderings and promises of parks, playgrounds and “cranes on the skyline” within months.

articles.headline: Seeking Alternatives to Animal-Derived Drugs
articles.snippet: Concern about the possibility of animal viruses has led to a renewed search for synthetic replacements for certain crucial medicines that are still derived from animal parts.
articles.abstract: Concern about the possibility of animal viruses has led to a renewed search for synthetic replacements for certain crucial medicines that are still derived from animal parts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chopped pig pancreas may not sound appetizing. But most cystic fibrosis patients eat a refined version of it each breakfast, lunch and dinner  five large capsules a meal  to supply enzymes their bodies do not produce.
